Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Scarf Osteotomy for Hallux Valgus Correction

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 29 patients (34 feet) with hallux valgus were recruited from a single orthopedic center.

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they had symptomatic hallux valgus requiring surgical intervention.

Intervention.evidence: They were randomised to undergo scarf osteotomy with distal soft tissue realignment.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the effectiveness of scarf osteotomy in improving deformity and patient satisfaction.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS) scores from baseline to a minimum follow-up of 12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 29 patients (34 feet) with hallux valgus were recruited from a single orthopedic center.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean AOFAS scores improved from 61.5 to 90.3.

Harms.evidence: Complications included superficial wound infection (one), recurrence (two), and troughing (three).
